module.title: Remote Repositories
module.description: Learn to connect with remote repositories and collaborate with others

lessons.title: Understanding Remote Repositories
lessons.content:
# Essential to know
- Remote repositories are copies of your repo hosted elsewhere (GitHub, GitLab, etc.)
- `origin` is the default name for your main remote
- You can have multiple remotes
- Remotes enable collaboration and backup
- Git is distributed - you have a full copy of the repository

---

# Understanding Remote Repositories

Remote repositories allow you to collaborate with others and keep backups of your code on services like GitHub, GitLab, or Bitbucket.

## What is a Remote?

A remote is a version of your repository hosted on the internet or network:

```
Your Computer          Remote Server (GitHub)
    ↓                         ↓
Local Repo  ←——————→  Remote Repo
    ↑        push/pull       ↑
  Working                  Shared
```

## Common Remote Services

- **GitHub**: Most popular, great for open source
- **GitLab**: Open source alternative, built-in CI/CD
- **Bitbucket**: Atlassian product, integrates with Jira
- **Azure DevOps**: Microsoft's solution

## The Origin

When you clone a repository, Git automatically names the remote `origin`:

```bash
# This creates a remote called 'origin'
git clone https://github.com/user/repo.git
```

You can see this with:
```bash
git remote -v
# origin  https://github.com/user/repo.git (fetch)
# origin  https://github.com/user/repo.git (push)
```

## Local vs Remote

| Local | Remote |
|-------|--------|
| On your computer | On a server |
| Private work | Shared with team |
| Fast operations | Network required |
| Full history | Full history |

## Workflow Overview

```
1. Work locally on a branch
2. Commit your changes
3. Push commits to remote
4. Others pull your changes
5. Collaborate!
```

## Why Use Remotes?

1. **Backup**: Your code is safe on a server
2. **Collaboration**: Multiple people can contribute
3. **Sharing**: Open source or showcase your work
4. **CI/CD**: Automated testing and deployment
5. **Documentation**: README, wikis, issues

lessons.title: Cloning Repositories
lessons.content:
# Essential to know
- `git clone` downloads a complete copy of a remote repository
- It automatically sets up the 'origin' remote
- Creates a local folder with the project name
- You get the full history, all branches, and everything
- Use HTTPS or SSH URLs

---

# Cloning Repositories

Cloning is how you get a copy of an existing remote repository onto your local machine.

## Basic Clone

```bash
# Clone a repository
git clone https://github.com/user/repository.git

# This creates a folder called 'repository'
# and downloads everything into it
```

## Clone with Custom Folder Name

```bash
# Clone into a specific folder name
git clone https://github.com/user/repo.git my-project

# Now it's in the 'my-project' folder instead of 'repo'
```

## Clone URLs

You can use different URL formats:

### HTTPS (easiest for beginners)
```bash
git clone https://github.com/user/repo.git
# You'll be prompted for username/password
```

### SSH (more secure, no passwords)
```bash
git clone git@github.com:user/repo.git
# Requires SSH key setup
```

### GitHub CLI
```bash
gh repo clone user/repo
```

## What Happens When You Clone?

1. Downloads all files and folders
2. Downloads complete history (all commits)
3. Downloads all branches
4. Sets up 'origin' remote automatically
5. Checks out the default branch (usually main)

## After Cloning

```bash
# Go into the project folder
cd repository

# Check the remote
git remote -v
# Shows: origin  https://github.com/user/repo.git

# See all branches
git branch -a
# Shows local and remote branches
```

## Cloning Specific Branches

```bash
# Clone only a specific branch
git clone --branch feature-name --single-branch https://github.com/user/repo.git

# Clone with all branches (default)
git clone https://github.com/user/repo.git
```

## Shallow Clone (Faster)

For large repositories, clone only recent history:

```bash
# Clone only the last 10 commits
git clone --depth 10 https://github.com/user/repo.git
```
lessons.codeExample:

git clone https://github.com/username/project.git

# Clone into a custom folder
git clone https://github.com/username/project.git my-folder

# Clone a specific branch only

lessons.title: Managing Remotes
lessons.content:
# Essential to know
- `git remote -v` lists all remotes
- `git remote add name url` adds a new remote
- `git remote remove name` removes a remote
- `git remote rename old new` renames a remote
- You can have multiple remotes (origin, upstream, etc.)

---

# Managing Remotes

Learn to add, remove, and manage connections to remote repositories.

## Viewing Remotes

```bash
# List all remotes
git remote

# List with URLs
git remote -v

# Show details about a specific remote
git remote show origin
```

## Adding a Remote

```bash
# Add a new remote called 'origin'
git remote add origin https://github.com/user/repo.git

# Add another remote (e.g., upstream for forks)
git remote add upstream https://github.com/original/repo.git
```

## Common Remote Names

- **origin**: Your fork or main repository (default)
- **upstream**: The original repository (when you forked)
- **backup**: A secondary backup location
- **deploy**: A deployment server

## Removing a Remote

```bash
# Remove a remote
git remote remove origin

# Or use the shorter version
git remote rm origin
```

## Renaming a Remote

```bash
# Rename 'origin' to 'github'
git remote rename origin github
```

## Changing Remote URL

```bash
# Change the URL of an existing remote
git remote set-url origin https://new-url.com/repo.git

# Switch from HTTPS to SSH
git remote set-url origin git@github.com:user/repo.git
```

## Fork Workflow Example

When contributing to open source:

```bash
# 1. Fork on GitHub, then clone your fork
git clone https://github.com/YOUR-USERNAME/repo.git

# 2. Add the original as 'upstream'
git remote add upstream https://github.com/ORIGINAL-OWNER/repo.git

# 3. Now you have:
git remote -v
# origin    https://github.com/YOUR-USERNAME/repo.git
# upstream  https://github.com/ORIGINAL-OWNER/repo.git
```

## Fetching from Multiple Remotes

```bash
# Fetch from origin
git fetch origin

# Fetch from upstream
git fetch upstream

# Fetch from all remotes
git fetch --all
```

# Change remote URL

lessons.title: Pushing to Remotes
lessons.content:
# Essential to know
- `git push` uploads your commits to a remote
- `git push origin branch-name` pushes a specific branch
- `git push -u origin branch` sets upstream for tracking
- You need write access to push to a remote
- Pushing shares your work with others

---

# Pushing to Remotes

Pushing uploads your local commits to a remote repository, making them available to others.

## Basic Push

```bash
# Push current branch to origin
git push

# Push specific branch
git push origin feature-branch

# Push main branch
git push origin main
```

## First Push (Set Upstream)

When pushing a new branch for the first time:

```bash
# Push and set upstream (tracking)
git push -u origin feature-branch

# Or the longer version
git push --set-upstream origin feature-branch
```

After this, you can just use `git push` on that branch.

## What is Upstream?

Upstream links your local branch to a remote branch:

```
Local: feature-branch  →  Remote: origin/feature-branch
              ↑
         (upstream tracking)
```

With upstream set:
- `git push` knows where to push
- `git pull` knows where to pull from

## Push Options

```bash
# Force push (use with caution!)
git push --force
git push -f

# Push all branches
git push --all origin

# Push tags
git push --tags

# Push specific tag
git push origin v1.0.0
```

## ⚠️ Force Push Warning

Force push overwrites remote history:

```bash
# DANGER: This can delete others' work!
git push --force
```

Only use force push if:
- You're the only one working on the branch
- You just rebased and need to update
- You know exactly what you're doing

Safer alternative:
```bash
git push --force-with-lease
```

## Deleting Remote Branches

```bash
# Delete remote branch
git push origin --delete old-branch

# Shorthand syntax
git push origin :old-branch
```

## Push Workflow

```bash
# 1. Make changes and commit locally
git add .
git commit -m "Add new feature"

# 2. Push to remote
git push origin feature-branch

# 3. Create pull request on GitHub/GitLab
# 4. After merge, delete local branch
git branch -d feature-branch
```
lessons.codeExample:
# Push current branch
git push

# Push specific branch
git push origin main

# Push new branch and set upstream
git push -u origin feature-login

# Push all tags
git push --tags

# Delete remote branch
git push origin --delete old-branch

lessons.title: Pulling and Fetching
lessons.content:
# Essential to know
- `git fetch` downloads changes from remote but doesn't merge
- `git pull` downloads AND merges changes (fetch + merge)
- `git pull --rebase` applies your changes on top of remote changes
- Fetch is safer - lets you review before merging
- Pull can create merge conflicts

---

# Pulling and Fetching

Fetching and pulling are how you get changes from remote repositories.

## git fetch

Fetch downloads commits, files, and branches from remote:

```bash
# Fetch from origin
git fetch origin

# Fetch from all remotes
git fetch --all
```

What fetch does:
- Downloads new commits
- Updates remote branch pointers (origin/main)
- Does NOT change your working directory
- Does NOT merge anything

## Checking Fetched Changes

```bash
# See what changed on remote
git log main..origin/main

# See commits that are on origin but not local
git log --oneline main..origin/main
```

## git pull

Pull fetches AND merges in one command:

```bash
# Pull from origin (fetch + merge)
git pull

# Pull specific branch
git pull origin main
```

## Pull with Rebase

Instead of merging, rebase puts your commits on top:

```bash
# Fetch and rebase
git pull --rebase

# Or configure as default
git config --global pull.rebase true
```

**Merge vs Rebase:**

```
Merge:              Rebase:
A---B---C---M       A---B---C---D'---E'
     \   /                    ↑
      D---E                 Your commits replayed
```

## Fetch vs Pull: When to Use

**Use fetch when:**
- You want to review changes before merging
- You're not ready to merge yet
- You want to see what others have done

**Use pull when:**
- You're ready to integrate changes
- You're working alone on the branch
- You want the quickest workflow

## Complete Workflow

```bash
# 1. Fetch to see what's new
git fetch origin

# 2. Check what changed
git log --oneline main..origin/main

# 3. If it looks good, merge
git merge origin/main

# Or do it all at once
git pull
```

## Handling Pull Conflicts

If pull creates conflicts:

```bash
git pull
# Auto-merging file.txt
# CONFLICT (content): Merge conflict in file.txt

# Fix conflicts in the files
# Then complete the merge
git add .
git commit -m "Merge remote changes"
```
lessons.codeExample:
# Fetch changes from remote
git fetch origin

# Fetch all remotes
git fetch --all

# Pull (fetch + merge)
git pull

# Pull with rebase
git pull --rebase

# See what changed on remote
git log --oneline main..origin/main

questions.question: What is a remote repository?
options: A local backup of your files
A version of your repository hosted on a server (like GitHub)
A branch inside your local repository
A special folder in .git
questions.explanation: A remote repository is a version of your project hosted on a server like GitHub, GitLab, or Bitbucket. It enables collaboration and serves as a backup.

questions.question: What is 'origin' in Git?
options: The first commit in a repository
The main branch
The default name for the remote repository
The user who created the repo
questions.explanation: When you clone a repository, Git automatically names the remote 'origin'. It's just a convention — you can rename it or add additional remotes with different names.

questions.question: What does 'git clone' do?
options: Creates an empty repository
Downloads a complete copy of a remote repository including all history
Copies only the latest version of files
Creates a branch on the remote
questions.explanation: git clone downloads the entire repository including all files, branches, and complete commit history. It also automatically sets up the 'origin' remote.

questions.question: What is a 'shallow clone'?
options: A clone that only copies one branch
A clone that downloads only recent history (using --depth)
A clone without the .git folder
A clone from a private repository
questions.explanation: A shallow clone (using --depth N) downloads only the last N commits instead of the full history. This is useful for large repositories when you don't need the complete history.

questions.question: How do you add a new remote called 'upstream'?
options: git remote upstream https://url.git
git remote add upstream https://url.git
git add remote upstream https://url.git
git upstream add https://url.git
questions.explanation: The syntax is 'git remote add <name> <url>'. The 'upstream' remote is commonly used when forking to point to the original repository.

questions.question: When would you have multiple remotes?
options: Never, you can only have one
When you fork a project (origin for your fork, upstream for the original)
Only when using GitLab
Only for private repositories
questions.explanation: Multiple remotes are common when contributing to open source. 'origin' points to your fork, while 'upstream' points to the original repository. You can also have remotes for different hosting services.

questions.question: What does 'git push -u origin feature' do?
options: Deletes the feature branch from origin
Pushes the branch and sets up tracking between local and remote branches
Creates a new repository on origin
Undoes the last push
questions.explanation: The -u (or --set-upstream) flag pushes the branch and creates a tracking relationship. After this, you can just use 'git push' and 'git pull' without specifying the remote and branch.

questions.question: Why is 'git push --force' dangerous?
options: It's actually perfectly safe
It can overwrite remote history and destroy other people's work
It deletes the repository
It removes all branches
questions.explanation: Force push overwrites the remote branch with your local version, potentially destroying commits that others have pushed. Use --force-with-lease as a safer alternative, or avoid force pushing on shared branches.

questions.question: What is the difference between git fetch and git pull?
options: fetch downloads and merges, pull only downloads
fetch only downloads, pull downloads and merges
They are the same command
fetch is for branches, pull is for files
questions.explanation: git fetch downloads changes from the remote but doesn't modify your working directory or merge anything. git pull does both: it fetches and then automatically merges. Fetch is safer because you can review changes first.

questions.question: What does 'git pull --rebase' do differently from a regular pull?
options: It downloads faster
Instead of merging, it replays your local commits on top of the remote changes
It only pulls from the upstream remote
It pulls without downloading any files
questions.explanation: git pull --rebase fetches remote changes and then replays your local commits on top, creating a linear history instead of a merge commit. This keeps the commit history cleaner.

questions.question: How do you delete a remote branch?
options: git branch -d remote/branch-name
git push origin --delete branch-name
git remote delete branch-name
git delete origin/branch-name
questions.explanation: To delete a branch on the remote, use 'git push origin --delete branch-name'. This only removes the remote copy — your local branch remains until you delete it with 'git branch -d'.

questions.question: What does 'origin/main' represent?
options: Your local main branch
A special branch for origin
A remote-tracking branch that mirrors the state of main on origin
The default file in the repository
questions.explanation: origin/main is a remote-tracking branch — it's a local reference that represents the last known state of the main branch on the origin remote. It's updated when you fetch or pull.

questions.question: What is the recommended workflow before pushing to a shared branch?
options: Just push directly
Pull (or fetch + merge) the latest changes first, resolve any conflicts, then push
Delete the branch and recreate it
Force push to override everything
questions.explanation: Before pushing, always pull the latest changes to make sure you're up to date. This prevents rejected pushes and lets you resolve any conflicts locally before sharing your work.

questions.question: In a fork-based workflow, where do you push your changes?
options: To the upstream (original) repository directly
To your fork (origin), then create a pull request to upstream
To a new repository each time
You can't push when using forks
questions.explanation: In a fork workflow, you push to your own fork (origin), then create a pull request on the original repository (upstream) to propose your changes. This allows maintainers to review your code before merging.
